awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH:   The Evolutionary Significance of Gametophyte Morphology in Epiphytic Ferns
awd_abstract_narration:
During the Cretaceous, flowering plants diversified rapidly and quickly became the dominant group of plants on the planet. Their rise pushed several other plant lineages to extinction or severely reduced their diversity. Ferns are the only exception to this pattern. Rather than being marginalized or driven to extinction, ferns actually thrived and diversified in both the forest understory and the newly available canopy. Ferns and lycophytes are unique among land plants in having two independent stages of the life cycle (haploid gametophyte and diploid sporophyte), both of which had to adapt to the new environmental conditions created by the rise of flowering plants. Many tropical, epiphytic fern gametophytes evolved to produce more leaves than their terrestrial counterparts, which enable them to live longer and to reproduce without producing spores. These are highly beneficial traits in the competitive canopy environment that may actually have enabled ferns to diversify rapidly in these habitats. The increased independence of the gametophyte means that ferns can postpone the production of sporophytes if conditions are unfavorable. As a result, in several epiphytic species we observe a pattern of spatially separated generations, in which the gametophyte can grow in a much broader range of conditions than its sporophyte. Several of these fern species with long-lived gametophytes grow in Hawaii, where ferns remain understudied. This project will investigate the ecology of these ferns in Hawaii, particularly the environmental conditions that favor the evolution of independent gametophyte populations. Temperature, light levels, and precipitation will all be measured in order to understand the ecological dynamics that govern sporophyte and gametophyte production. One graduate student and several undergraduates from the University of Florida and University of Hawaii at Manoa will be trained in diverse field and laboratory methods. Results from the study will be broadly disseminated via popular science articles.

This research will survey sporophyte and independent gametophyte floras at five stations in the Koolau and Waianae Mountain ranges of Hawaii at 200, 400, 800, and 1,000 m intervals. At each site, researchers will collect epiphytic sporophytes in 10 X 10 m square plots located off the trail, measure the size of fronds, and preserve tissue for herbarium collections and DNA extraction. Temperature and light levels will be measured using Onset HOBO data loggers, and precipitation will be recorded with standard tipping bucket rain gauges. Environmental conditions will be measured over the course of one year. The results of this study will allow researchers to determine what conditions prevent sporophyte production in ferns, and provide new insights into the diversity and evolution of ferns on the Hawaiian Islands.

por.por_cntn:
Ferns are a diverse group of land plants that (along with lycophytes) are unique in having two independent stages of the life cycle: a haploid gametophyte stage and a diploid sporophyte stage. Like most other land plants, the sporophyte is the dominant phase of the life cycle for ferns, and fern sporophytes are typically large, green, photosynthetic, and easily recognizable as ferns. The gametophyte generation is typically miniscule and ephemeral, but it is also, however, critical for population establishment and species longevity, as it is where sexual reproduction takes place. In a number of ferns (approximately 26 species worldwide), a pattern has been observed in which these generations are spatially separated, meaning that the ranges of a particular species' gametophytes and sporophytes are not identical, with the gametophytes typically having a wider geographic range and putatively able to tolerate a greater variety of conditions than the sporophytes. Very little research has been done to actually try to figure out what environmental parameters might contribute to this pattern, and whether gametophytes truly are tolerant of a wider range of environmental parameters than their own sporophytes.

 

This project investigated the ecology of several ferns that demonstrate the separation of generations pattern, including in south Florida and Hawaii. We measured rainfall, temperature, and relative humidity using data loggers in the field, in order to understand the ecological dynamics that govern sporophyte and gametophyte production. We found evidence for small but significant differences in these parameters between populations that produce sporophytes and those that only ever have gametophytes present. We conclude that environmental factors do play an important role in determining whether sporophytes can survive in a particular population, and we suggest numerous avenues for future study, including adding additional environmental parameters to future work, studying the timing of gamete production relative to various environmental factors, and expanding to include additional sites and species.

 

This work has increased our understanding of the basic biology of ferns and the effects of the environment on fern reproduction and sporophyte production, which is crucial for understanding the evolutionary dynamics of these plants. In particular, climate change is likely to alter environments in unpredictable ways, and knowing that even small differences in temperature and relative humidity can have an impact on fern reproduction will help inform us about how these plants are likely to respond to a changing climate.
